Maternity leave not paid unless you have enough sick leave stored up to cover (takes about 2 years to acquire).

pros: Pros don't matter because they never out weighted the cons.
cons: Has serious political issues where the organization is divided by its departments and functions, advertising a space all about 'collaboration' but without the culture to support it. Everyone fights over money and plays petty games. People actively spend their time playing politics, fighting over money, degrading their co-workers, creating a hostile to inept work environment. They know about their issues and put out surveys as if they care but never do anything about it. Development and training was completely non-existent and you were expected to figure most stuff out yourself and if asking for help you were looked down upon or given poor treatment by outside departments that were suppose to be supportive. There was no room for growth unless you played politics and people actively would remind you of your 'place'. Turnover is excessive creating serious issues in coverage and accountability but they do not care enough to practice efforts towards retention. Pay is terrible-they refuse to give you more money no matter how hard you work and are actively in the act of firing and letting people go because of budget issues while spending tens of thousands of dollars on swag to give away.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros: Tuition and part of health insurance is covered Interactions with different kind of people
cons: Finding and paying for parking

pros: Freedom, work life balance. co-workers
cons: Pay, work load, time, hours

pros: People almost always work hard, do a good job, try to help each other, and help students. There may be some "quiet quitting" here and there, but I think it is largely due to exhaustion (see below) and generally not to poor leadership or half-hearted employees. The current Chancellor (since 2021) is enthusiastic, organized, and efficient (and one of the most genuine motivational speakers I've ever heard) is streamlining departments to coordinate better effect change for the educational, research, and service aspects of the university. Although challenging, it has been exciting and I look forward to seeing real synergy across units, stronger student services, and better educational results. There really are a lot of innovative teaching and research activities going around campus that make it feel like an exciting and world-changing place. It is a diverse place to work with a pretty diverse student body: 5500 1st generation students (of 15,000 study body of grad/undergrad students) which makes up 41% of the undergraduate student body. 4000+ students are from under-represented areas. Administrators are often open to new ideas if they reach the right person at a good time, and there are always new centers, programs, and projects that can tackle challenges or promote importantly ideas or changes. It also means as staff that there are occasionally ways to move around or up into new types of roles or positions for special programs, which universities may not always be able to offer given the fairly flat administrative structure and limited advancement opportunities in Higher Ed overall.
cons: UNO is 3rd on the list of priorities for the Board of Regents, and although the only urban public university in Nebraska with amazing connections to businesses, internships, research opportunities, and non-profit communities, departments and units must be incredibly sparing with funds for anything. The limited funds means that many departments are unable to invest faculty or staff time into as projects and special programs. In some places it means there are long delays in getting paperwork processed, updating systems needs, or accessing information. In areas where there is limited staffing for student resources, it also means communication is not always strong or very efficient - to students or faculty/staff - and tracking of resources or their efficiency is more than likely lacking or fragile, occurring because of a person in a department who wants to make sure it happens rather than an institutional oversight process that can offer more resources or longevity after that person is not longer there. Most often the funding challenges mean that people are always asked to do a lot, and while UNO is a great place to find passional people who care about people, education, and communities, that also makes it a place to find people who feel on edge, exhausted, overwhelmed, or fraying around the edges.

pros:
(Quick Takes)
- Great opportunity to make professional connections in Omaha
- Develop relationships with future professionals 
- gain skills, knowledge, and abilities to address issues like microaggressions, redlining, and other concepts related to poverty and race

(Long take)
The Service Learning Academy (SLA) is an excellent place to work. On a professional level, you work with many non-profits, businesses, and government agencies which is a great way to get your foot in the door for future employment. Additionally, their efforts to tackle the issues of race in poverty, and provide students with real-world experiences outside of the classroom, help you to feel like you are making the community a better place. You make wonderful connections with people both inside and outside the non-profit. SLA also looks for ways to develop workers within their areas of interest or study so they can gain experience, skills, and knowledge for their futures. At the time I was working there, I believed I wanted to work in HR so they gave me opportunities to be part of the interview process as well as create videos regarding how to address conflicts and properly manage projects.
cons:
(Quick Takes)
- Poor communication including top-down communication
- fails to develop the organization itself
- fails to address criticisms properly
- While it is getting better, it has a history of hiring predominantly white women
- has gotten better but still sometimes had workers that targeted people of color for complaints

(Long take)
SLA has its share of issues. One of the main issues is communication, specifically regarding top-down communication. Sometimes, the staff fails to recognize the demands outside of work. They often communicate too little and too late, leaving expectations unmet and the worker in question being held accountable even though they did nothing wrong. Other issues include not taking more opportunities for the non-profit to grow. The organization has passed up on opportunities to develop a marketing team, participate in current movements (e.g. pride month, black history month, etc.), and address common internal issues that prevent them from improving. Moreover, the organizations fail to take these criticisms, and the cycle of shooting itself in the foot repreats.

pros: Collaborative environment with a group of fantastic co-workers who are very student-centered.  Generally relaxed atmosphere and a great salary for lead teachers.  Nice community in Omaha.  Good benefits for travel and professional development if you're full-time or if you're part-time and get accepted to speak at a conference.  Fairly flexible and reasonably teaching and organizational policies with easy-to-work-with administrators sympathetic to the realistic demands on your personal and professional time.
cons: As with a lot of IEPs, a lot of the teaching relies on part-time instructors who work multiple places, which means that everyone always seems busy and things can easily get lost despite many emails and conversations.  The program relies a lot of teachers to work efficiently, and during busy periods of the session, it can feel as though there isn't enough time for teaching prep, student advising, grading, and admin oversight.  And since there are 6 back-to-back sessions per year, parts of the year can feel like a sprint.

pros: Good benefits including 15 hours tuition/year for full-time employees. Interesting and rewarding to be working around students. Relaxed, relatively flat management structure overall. Friendly, nice people to work with. Great place to be if you like a university environment.
cons: Lack of advancement opportunities for employees. Employees are often treated as second-class citizens and have no voice in governance or management structure, even though they are running the place. Working in colleges or units with faculty is very challenging, as faculty have high expectations. Pay should be more competitive to retain high quality employees. The campus is going through severe growing pains, which is creating stress and needs to be managed appropriately.
